Failure to launch an investigation into genocide in Gaza and issue arrest warrants can have a devastating impact on the International Criminal Court. Last month, our organisation, Law for Palestine, made the first in a series of submissions to the ICC, characterising the crime of genocide committed by Israeli leaders against the Palestinian people. The 200-page document, drafted by 30 lawyers and legal researchers from across the world and reviewed by more than 15 experts, makes a compelling case for the genocidal intent as well as for the prosecutorial policy that the court has followed in other cases. If the ICC fails to act once again, it risks undermining its own authority as an institution of international justice and the international legal regime as a whole.

Police interrupt "Palestine Congress": Freedom of expression restricted in Berlin? The "Palestine Congress" was unexpectedly interrupted by the Berlin authorities today, just one hour after it began. The police intervened for reasons that initially remained unclear. It is believed that Salman Abu Sitta's speech, in which he compared the situation in Gaza to the Holocaust and the genocide in Rwanda, was the reason for the measure. This incident raises serious questions about freedom of expression in Berlin. Should a critical discussion about the situation in Palestine be suppressed? Should analogies between current conflicts and historical tragedies be taboo? Restricting freedom of expression in this way leaves room for speculation about the authorities' actual intentions. Berlin, a city once known for its liberal attitude and spirit of openness, now seems to be in the grip of restrictions. This incident will undoubtedly trigger further discussions about the limits of freedom of expression and the role of the authorities in regulating public events. It remains to be seen how the authorities will react to the criticism and whether the "Palestine Congress" will be allowed to continue at a later date. Until then, the debate about freedom of expression in Berlin and beyond will continue.

UK Judges‚Äô and Lawyers‚Äô Open Letter Concerning Gaza We are UK-based or qualified lawyers, legal academics and former members of the judiciary committed to upholding the rule of law and to protecting fundamental rights; and who share deep concern about the catastrophe unfolding in the Gaza Strip. In a letter dated 26 October 2023, over a thousand members of the legal profession wrote to you concerning your Government‚Äôs obligations to avert and avoid complicity in serious breaches of International Humanitarian Law (‚ÄúIHL‚Äù) in Gaza. Since that letter, there have been significant developments in relation to the situation in Gaza. These include the provisional order of the International Court of Justice dated 26 January 2024, by which the Court concluded that there was a plausible risk of genocide in Gaza; UN Security Council Resolution 2728 on 25 March 2024 demanding an immediate ceasefire during the month of Ramadan; and the worsening situation in Gaza, where the UN and international aid agencies warn of imminent famine, and where a ground offensive is threatened in Rafah, the last place of refuge for two-thirds of the population. We write in the light of these developments to remind you of your Government‚Äôs obligations under international law, which require you to take, amongst others, the following five actions: to work actively and effectively to secure a permanent ceasefire in Gaza; to take all available measures to ensure safe access to and delivery of the essentials of existence and medical assistance to Palestinians in Gaza, including confirmation that UK funding to UNRWA will continue with immediate effect; to impose sanctions upon individuals and entities who have made statements inciting genocide against Palestinians; to suspend the provision of weapons and weapons systems to the Government of Israel; and to suspend the 2030 Road Map for UK-Israel bilateral relations and negotiations towards an enhanced trade agreement and to initiate a review into the suspension of the UK‚Äôs bilateral trade agreement with Israel and consider the imposition of sanctions.

In a statement released by the president's office, the government of Maldives cited the "genocidal acts perpetrated by Israeli occupying forces under the guise of security concerns that have resulted in mass displacement, acute starvation, and blockage of humanitarian aid" as the reason for its decision.
